body.p: We read with great interest the recent article by Mirdamadi et al[1], titled “Preoperative risk factors for laparoscopic to open appendectomy conversion: a systematic review and meta-analysis.” This study presents a comprehensive synthesis of preoperative risk factors associated with the conversion from laparoscopic appendectomy (LA) to open appendectomy (OA), offering valuable evidence to inform surgical decision-making in the management of acute abdominal emergencies.

One of the key strengths of this study lies in its rigorous methodology and extensive data coverage. The authors systematically searched four major databases—PubMed, Web of Science, Scopus, and Embase—and included 45 studies encompassing a total sample size of over 3.2 million patients. The large-scale dataset lends substantial statistical power and generalizability to the findings. The authors categorized the risk factors into four major domains—demographic, clinical, laboratory, and radiological—enabling a structured and clinically interpretable analysis. Furthermore, the study adhered strictly to PRISMA and AMSTAR guidelines, and applied the Joanna Briggs Institute appraisal tool alongside the GRADE framework to assess study quality and evidence certainty, thereby enhancing methodological transparency and reliability.

According to the findings, advanced age, male sex, obesity, ASA classification III–IV, history of previous abdominal surgery, prolonged symptom duration, fever, higher Alvarado score, elevated inflammatory markers (such as C-reactive protein and neutrophil percentage), and radiologic findings such as increased appendiceal diameter and intraabdominal fluid were all significantly associated with conversion from LA to OA. In addition, meta-regression analysis revealed a declining trend in conversion rates over time, likely reflecting technological advancements in laparoscopy and the accumulation of surgical expertise—an observation with important clinical implications.

Nevertheless, several aspects merit further discussion. First, the majority of included studies were retrospective, introducing the potential for selection and information bias. Second, factors such as surgeon experience, hospital level, and technological platform were inconsistently reported and therefore not included in quantitative synthesis. Third, some comorbidities—such as diabetes, hypertension, and cardiovascular disease—lacked multivariate adjustment, limiting the ability to determine their independent effects. Finally, the presence of substantial heterogeneity across studies, although partially explored via meta-regression, suggests that findings should be cautiously generalized across different clinical settings.

Building on the insights provided by this study, future research may focus on several directions: (1) development and validation of preoperative risk prediction models based on identified risk factors, to support individualized surgical decision-making; (2) large-scale, prospective, multicenter cohort studies to strengthen the evidence base and external validity of findings; and (3) integration of these predictive factors into emerging management strategies, such as non-operative treatment and interval appendectomy, to inform patient selection and outcome optimization.

In conclusion, the study by Mirdamadi et al provides robust and comprehensive evidence regarding preoperative risk factors for conversion from LA to OA. It not only contributes meaningfully to the existing literature in the field but also offers valuable guidance for optimizing clinical practice and designing future research.
